questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for diagnosis of Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare acquired hematologic disorder caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to the absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of red blood cells, leukocytes, and platelets. This makes the red blood cells more susceptible to complement-mediated hemolysis.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Sucrose Lysis Test
    • An older screening test that induces hemolysis in low ionic strength (hypotonic) conditions, increasing complement binding.
    • Not specific and has been replaced by flow cytometry.
  • (Choice B) Ham Test (Acidified Serum Lysis Test)
    • Detects complement-mediated hemolysis in acidic conditions.
    • Historically used but now obsolete due to its low sensitivity and specificity.
  • (Choice D) Bone Marrow Aspiration
    • Bone marrow examination may show hypocellularity, but it is not diagnostic for PNH.
    • It is useful in ruling out other bone marrow failure syndromes like aplastic anemia or myelodysplastic syndromes (which can coexist with PNH).

Clinical Relevance of Flow Cytometry in PNH:

  • Helps diagnose PNH-associated thrombosis, which can occur in unusual sites like the hepatic, mesenteric, or cerebral veins.
  • Guides treatment decisions, including the use of Eculizumab (C5 inhibitor therapy).
  • Monitors disease progression and helps in evaluating bone marrow failure syndromes.

Key takeaway:

Flow cytometry is the gold standard test for PNH because it directly detects the absence of GPI-anchored proteins such as CD55 (Decay-Accelerating Factor) and CD59 (Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis) on red blood cells and granulocytes.

  • Highly sensitive and specific, capable of detecting as little as 0.01% of PNH clones.
  • Can differentiate PNH from other hemolytic anemias and monitor clonal expansion over time.

questions.text: A 49 year old male, chronic smoker and alcoholic came with complaints over epigastric region radiating to back associated with pale-colored stools. Pain usually increases or aggravated by eating or alcohol consumption. CT abdomen done as shown below. Most common cause of the condition discussed above is
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, including epigastric pain radiating to the back, pale-colored stools (steatorrhea), and worsening with food or alcohol consumption, along with the CT findings, strongly suggest chronic pancreatitis.

Most Common Cause: Alcohol (Choice A)

  • Chronic alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis (70-80% of cases).
  • Alcohol induces repeated pancreatic injury, leading to progressive inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of exocrine function.
  • Calcifications in the pancreas, seen on CT imaging, are characteristic of chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice B) Gallstones:
    • Gallstone disease is a major cause of acute pancreatitis, not chronic pancreatitis.
    • Chronic pancreatitis due to gallstones is less common and usually occurs in patients with recurrent acute pancreatitis episodes.
  • (Choice C) Trauma:
    • Trauma can cause acute pancreatitis, but chronic pancreatitis from trauma is rare and usually seen in severe pancreatic injuries.
  • (Choice D) Smoking:
    • Smoking is a risk factor but is not the most common cause.
    • It accelerates the progression of chronic pancreatitis in alcoholics but is not an independent leading cause.

Key takeaway:

  • Chronic, progressive epigastric pain that worsens with meals and alcohol.
  • Malabsorption (steatorrhea, weight loss) due to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
  • Diabetes mellitus (late-stage complication due to endocrine dysfunction).
  • Pancreatic calcifications on CT scan or X-ray (a hallmark of chronic disease).

questions.text: Lymphohistiocytic variant of Reed Sternberg cell is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells is characteristic of Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL), a distinct subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma. These cells are also referred to as "Popcorn cells" due to their lobulated, folded nuclear appearance.

Key Features of Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (LPHL):

  1. L&H (Popcorn) Cells
    • These cells express CD20, CD45, and BCL6, but lack CD15 and CD30, which are typically seen in classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL).
  2. Nodular Growth Pattern
    • LPHL has a nodular architecture with abundant small lymphocytes and histiocytes surrounding the L&H cells.
  3. Immunophenotype Distinction
    • LPHL (Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma):
      • CD20+, CD45+, BCL6+
      • CD15-, CD30-
    • Classical HL (e.g., Nodular Sclerosis, Mixed Cellularity):
      • CD15+, CD30+
      • CD20-

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Lymphocyte Rich HL
    • While this subtype has many lymphocytes, the RS cells here are classical (CD15+, CD30+), not L&H (Popcorn) cells.
    • It is a subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL).
  • (Choice C) Nodular Sclerosis HL
    • The hallmark cell in Nodular Sclerosis Hodgkin Lymphoma (NSHL) is the Lacunar cell, a subtype of Reed-Sternberg cell.
    • It is CD15+ and CD30+, typical of classical HL.
  • (Choice D) Mixed Cellularity HL
    • This subtype has abundant eosinophils, plasma cells, and classic RS cells, not Popcorn cells.
    • The RS cells in Mixed Cellularity HL are CD15+ and CD30+.

Key takeaway:

The Lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed-Sternberg cells, also known as Popcorn cells, is characteristic of Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL).

questions.text: Which of the following hematological problems may be precipitated by Parvovirus?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 is a single-stranded DNA virus that infects and destroys erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, leading to a temporary cessation of red blood cell production. This can precipitate a severe aplastic crisis in individuals with pre-existing chronic hemolytic disorders.

Why is Aplastic Crisis the Correct Answer?

  • Parvovirus B19 targets and destroys erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia.
  • In patients with underlying hemolytic anemia (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis, and thalassemia), this leads to a sudden and life-threatening drop in hemoglobin levels.
  • Reticulocytopenia (low reticulocyte count) is a hallmark feature.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Hemolytic Crisis
    • Parvovirus B19 does not directly cause hemolysis. Instead, it causes bone marrow suppression, leading to aplasia rather than an increase in hemolysis.
    • Hemolytic crisis is more commonly triggered by infections, oxidative stress (G6PD deficiency), or hypersplenism.
  • (Choice C) Pancytopenia
    • Transient pancytopenia can be seen in immunocompromised patients, but the main effect of Parvovirus B19 is on erythropoiesis.
    • Full-blown pancytopenia is not a common presentation in immunocompetent individuals.
  • (Choice D) Thrombocytopenia
    • Parvovirus B19 infection primarily affects red blood cell precursors, not platelets.
    • Thrombocytopenia is rare and usually secondary to bone marrow suppression in immunosuppressed patients.

Key takeaway:

Clinical Features of Parvovirus B19-Induced Aplastic Crisis:

  • Severe pallor, weakness, and fatigue due to a sudden drop in hemoglobin.
  • Low reticulocyte count (reticulocytopenia), confirming bone marrow suppression.
  • No splenomegaly, unlike hemolytic crises.
  • Self-limited condition, with recovery in 7–10 days in most cases.

Parvovirus B19 infection selectively suppresses erythropoiesis, leading to aplastic crisis in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease presented to ER complaining of approximately 1-2 weeks of neck pains radiating to his chest. The pains were associated with movement, particularly when he moved his head and neck. Other than his presenting symptoms, his review of symptoms was negative. His blood pressure was 126/67 mm HG and his pulse was 88 beats/min. Chest CT revealed no significant cardiac or pulmonary disease. However, a large ill-defined 4 cm right thyroid nodule was noted, associated with tracheal deviation at the thoracic inlet. TSH was normal at 1.18 mIU/ml. Hemithyroidectomy done and H&E stain was positive for nest of tumor cells and calcitonin shown below. RET proto-oncogene is associated with the most probable diagnosis discussed above:
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a large thyroid nodule (4 cm) causing tracheal deviation, normal TSH levels, and histological findings of tumor nests and calcitonin positivity. These features are highly suggestive of Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC), which originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid and is known for calcitonin production. Additionally, the association with the RET proto-oncogene further supports the diagnosis.

Why Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC)?

  • Derived from Parafollicular C cells, which secrete calcitonin.
  • Calcitonin positivity on immunohistochemistry (IHC) is a hallmark feature.
  • RET proto-oncogene mutations are commonly involved, especially in familial MTC or Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) 2A/2B syndromes.
  • Histopathology: Tumor cells appear in nests, trabeculae, or sheets with amyloid deposits (from calcitonin).

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice B) Follicular Thyroid Cancer (FTC)
    • Typically presents as a solitary, encapsulated nodule, often invading blood vessels.
    • Does not produce calcitonin.
    • RET mutations are not associated; instead, RAS and PAX8-PPARγ mutations are seen.
  • (Choice C) Papillary Thyroid Cancer (PTC)
    • Most common thyroid cancer, but characterized by Orphan Annie-eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.
    • Associated with BRAF and RET/PTC rearrangements, not typically with RET proto-oncogene mutations.
  • (Choice D) Anaplastic Thyroid Cancer (ATC)
    • Extremely aggressive, presents with rapidly growing thyroid mass and airway invasion.
    • No calcitonin production and RET mutations are not typical.
    • Poorly differentiated, often showing pleomorphic giant cells and spindle cells on histology.

Key takeaway:

The presence of calcitonin positivity, nest-like tumor cells, and RET proto-oncogene involvement confirms Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC)

The RET proto-oncogene is a key genetic driver in Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC). Germline mutations in RET are associated with familial MTC and Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, while somatic mutations in RET are found in sporadic cases of MTC.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice B) Follicular Thyroid Cancer (FTC)
    • Not associated with RET mutations.
    • Instead, RAS mutations and PAX8-PPARγ translocations are common.
    • Arises from follicular cells and spreads hematogenously.
  • (Choice C) Papillary Thyroid Cancer (PTC)
    • RET/PTC rearrangement (NOT RET mutations) is seen in PTC.
    • PTC is also linked with BRAF mutations (most common).
    • Characterized by Orphan Annie-eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.
  • (Choice D) Anaplastic Thyroid Cancer (ATC)
    • Highly aggressive thyroid malignancy.
    • No significant association with RET mutations.
    • Instead, it is associated with TP53 mutations, TERT promoter mutations, and dedifferentiation of PTC or FTC.

Key takeaway:

  • MTC arises from parafollicular C cells, which produce calcitonin.
  • Activating mutations in the RET proto-oncogene lead to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • RET mutations are present in:
    • Familial MTC (FMTC)
    • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) Type 2A & 2B
    • Sporadic MTC (~50% cases show RET mutations)

The RET proto-oncogene is strongly associated with Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC),

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate image of a patient with renal failure is shown below. What is the likely hematological disease associated with it?
questions.solution:
Bone Marrow Findings in a Patient with Renal Failure: Likely Hematological Disease

A bone marrow aspirate image in a patient with renal failure suggests a plasma cell dyscrasia, most commonly Multiple Myeloma (MM). Multiple myeloma is a neoplastic proliferation of monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to bone destruction, renal impairment, and hematological abnormalities.

Why is Multiple Myeloma (MM) the Correct Answer?

  • Renal failure is a hallmark feature of MM, caused by light chain deposition (Bence Jones proteinuria) and cast nephropathy.
  • Bone marrow aspirate shows increased plasma cells, often with atypical features such as binucleation and perinuclear clearing (hof).
  • Hypercalcemia, anemia, and bone lytic lesions are associated features.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) shows an M-spike, confirming monoclonal gammopathy.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
    • AML presents with increased myeloblasts, not plasma cells.
    • Does not typically cause renal failure as a primary feature.
  • (Choice B) Metastatic Cancer
    • Metastatic cancers in the bone marrow show malignant epithelial cells or marrow fibrosis, not plasma cell proliferation.
    • Most commonly associated with breast, lung, and prostate cancers.
  • (Choice D) Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)
    • MDS presents with dysplastic hematopoiesis affecting multiple lineages, not plasma cell proliferation.
    • Associated with macrocytic anemia and pancytopenia, not renal failure.

Key takeaway:

In a patient with renal failure and abnormal bone marrow findings, Multiple Myeloma (MM) is the most probable diagnosis, making option (C) the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin?
questions.solution:
Opsonins are molecules that enhance phagocytosis by marking pathogens for immune cells, such as macrophages and neutrophils. The complement system plays a major role in opsonization, with C3b and C5b being the key opsonins.

Why is C5b the Correct Answer?

  • C5b is an opsonin that binds to microbial surfaces, marking them for phagocytosis.
  • It is also involved in the formation of the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), leading to bacterial lysis.
  • C5b initiates the terminal complement cascade (C5b, C6, C7, C8, and C9).

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) C5a
    • Not an opsonin, but a potent anaphylatoxin and chemoattractant.
    • C5a recruits neutrophils and other immune cells to sites of infection.
  • (Choice C) C3a
    • Functions as an anaphylatoxin, promoting mast cell degranulation and inflammation.
    • Does not directly enhance phagocytosis.
  • (Choice D) C5a (Repeated Option)
    • As mentioned, C5a is a chemoattractant, not an opsonin.

Key takeaway

Opsonins in the Immune System:

  1. C3b & C5b (Complement system)
  2. IgG (Fc region binds to phagocyte receptors)
  3. Mannose-binding lectin (MBL)
  4. C-reactive protein (CRP)

choices.text: It is associated with elevated levels of growth factors
It has greater amount of collagen and vascularity
It does not spread beyond wound site
Wide excision may be done as a treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
The image clearly shows keloids, which are raised, firm, and rubbery or shiny scars that extend beyond the original wound site. This is a key characteristic that distinguishes keloids from hypertrophic scars, which remain confined to the boundaries of the initial injury.

(Choice C) it does not spread beyond wound site: This is FALSE. This is the defining characteristic of keloids. They DO spread beyond the original wound site.

Incorrect choices explanation :

(Choice A) it is associated with elevated levels of growth factors: This is TRUE. Keloids are associated with an overproduction of collagen, driven by elevated levels of growth factors like TGF-beta.

(Choice B) it has a greater amount of collagen and vascularity: This is TRUE. Keloids contain an excessive amount of collagen, leading to their raised and firm appearance. They also tend to have increased vascularity compared to normal scars.

(Choice D) wide excision may be done as a treatment: This is TRUE, but with caveats. Wide excision is a treatment option, but it's important to note that it often leads to recurrence, and additional treatments like radiation or corticosteroids are often used in conjunction with excision.

Why (Choice C) is the Correct Answer

The statement that keloids do not spread beyond the wound site is incorrect. This is the fundamental difference between keloids and hypertrophic scars.

Key takeaway:

Keloid:

Predisposition: Certain individuals are more prone to developing keloids, including people of African descent.

Location: Keloids are more common in certain areas of the body, such as the chest, shoulders, and earlobes.

questions.text: Small intestinal biopsy reveals PAS positive macrophages in the lamina propria as shown in the figure. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei that primarily affects the small intestine. The disease leads to malabsorption, weight loss, diarrhea, and systemic symptoms.

Why is Whipple's Disease the Correct Answer?

  • Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria, which contain non-acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) positivity indicates the presence of glycoprotein-rich bacterial debris within macrophages.
  • The hallmark histopathology is foamy macrophages in the lamina propria.
  • Systemic symptoms such as arthritis, neurological involvement (dementia, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia), and cardiac manifestations are common.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Gluten-Sensitive Enteropathy (Celiac Disease)
    • Celiac disease presents with villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia rather than PAS-positive macrophages.
    • Anti-tTG and Anti-EMA antibodies are diagnostic, and symptoms improve with a gluten-free diet.
  • (Choice C) Abetalipoproteinemia
    • A rare disorder with defective chylomicron formation, leading to fat malabsorption and acanthocytosis (spiky RBCs).
    • Small intestinal biopsy shows lipid accumulation in enterocytes, not PAS-positive macrophages.
  • (Choice D) Giardiasis
    • Caused by Giardia lamblia, leading to chronic diarrhea and malabsorption.
    • Characterized by pear-shaped trophozoites with flagella, seen in stool microscopy or duodenal biopsy, but not PAS-positive macrophages.

Key takeaway of Whipple's Disease

The presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria is a hallmark finding of Whipple's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is X-linked disease?
questions.solution:
Color blindness is an X-linked recessive disorder that primarily affects males because they have only one X chromosome (XY karyotype). Since males inherit their single X chromosome from their mother, an X-linked mutation is always expressed in them. In females (XX karyotype), a normal second X chromosome usually compensates for the defective one, making them carriers rather than affected individuals.

Types of Color Blindness:

  • Red-green color blindness (most common) - due to mutations in the OPN1LW (long wavelength, red) and OPN1MW (medium wavelength, green) genes located on the X chromosome.
  • Blue-yellow color blindness (Tritanopia) - autosomal, not X-linked.
  • Complete color blindness (achromatopsia) - usually autosomal recessive.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Thalassemia
    • Autosomal recessive, not X-linked.
    • Caused by mutations in the HBB gene (β-thalassemia) or HBA genes (α-thalassemia).
  • (Choice B) Galactosemia
    • Autosomal recessive, caused by GALT, GALK, or GALE gene mutations.
    • Leads to deficiency in galactose metabolism causing liver and CNS damage.
  • (Choice D) Sickle Cell Disease
    • Autosomal recessive, caused by a mutation in the HBB gene on chromosome 11.
    • Results in abnormal hemoglobin S, leading to sickling of RBCs.

Key takeaway of X-Linked Recessive Disorders:

  • More common in males (since they have only one X chromosome).
  • Females are usually carriers unless both X chromosomes are affected.
  • No male-to-male transmission (fathers pass the Y chromosome to sons).

Other Common X-Linked Recessive Disorders:

  • Hemophilia A & B
  • Duchenne and Becker Muscular Dystrophy
  • G6PD Deficiency
  • Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome
  • Fabry Disease

choices.text: Quantitative defects are seen in subtypes 1 and 3 one willebrand disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Von Willebrand disease?
questions.solution:
Why is Choice (C) Incorrect?

  • Hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints) is NOT a usual presentation of VWD.
  • Hemarthrosis is more characteristic of Hemophilia A or B (Factor VIII or IX deficiency), which affects the coagulation cascade more severely.
  • VWD usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis, menorrhagia, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts.

Why Are the Other Choices Correct?

  1. (Choice A) Normal platelet count → True
    • In VWD, platelet count is normal because it is a platelet function disorder, not a platelet production disorder.
    • However, platelet function is defective due to reduced vWF.
  2. (Choice B) Quantitative defects in subtypes 1 and 3 → True
    • Type 1 VWD: Mild-moderate quantitative deficiency of vWF (most common type, ~70-80%).
    • Type 3 VWD: Severe deficiency/complete absence of vWF (rare but severe).
    • Type 2 VWD: Qualitative defect (dysfunctional vWF rather than decreased quantity).
  3. (Choice D) Produced by endothelial cells → True
    • vWF is primarily synthesized and stored in endothelial cells (Weibel-Palade bodies) and megakaryocytes.
    • It plays a key role in platelet adhesion to damaged blood vessels.

Key takeaway:

Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand Factor (vWF). vWF is a glycoprotein produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes, essential for platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII in coagulation.

questions.text: Neuro endocrine tumor is having which of the following as an immunohistochemical marker?
questions.solution:
Neuroendocrine Tumor (NET) Immunohistochemical Marker

Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) originate from neuroendocrine cells, which have both neural and endocrine characteristics. The gold standard markers for diagnosing NETs include Synaptophysin and Chromogranin A, which are specific to neuroendocrine differentiation.

Why is Synaptophysin the Correct Answer?

  • Synaptophysin is a membrane glycoprotein found in presynaptic vesicles of neuroendocrine cells.
  • It is one of the most sensitive immunohistochemical markers for NETs, including:
    • Carcinoid tumors
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs)
    • Pheochromocytomas
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Small cell lung carcinoma
  • Synaptophysin is usually co-expressed with Chromogranin A, another neuroendocrine marker.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Cytokeratin
    • Cytokeratins (CKs) are epithelial markers, not specific for NETs.
    • Some NETs express low molecular weight cytokeratins (CK7, CK18, CK19), but this is not diagnostic for NETs alone.
  • (Choice B) Calretinin
    • Calretinin is a marker for mesothelial cells, commonly used in mesothelioma diagnosis.
    • It is not specific for neuroendocrine tumors.
  • (Choice D) Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)
    • CEA is a tumor marker elevated in colorectal, pancreatic, and gastric cancers.
    • Although some NETs (especially gastrointestinal carcinoids) may show CEA positivity, it is not a specific marker for neuroendocrine differentiation.

Other Key Immunohistochemical Markers for Neuroendocrine Tumors

Key takeaway:

Since Synaptophysin is the most sensitive marker for neuroendocrine tumors.

questions.text: A middle-aged adult undergoes orchiectomy. Looking at the gross and the histological findings, which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A middle-aged adult undergoing orchiectomy with specific gross and histopathological findings suggests a testicular germ cell tumor (GCT). Among the options provided, seminoma is the most common and likely diagnosis in this age group.

Incorrect Choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Lymphoma
    • Most common testicular tumor in men >60 years, but not in middle-aged adults.
    • Histology: Diffuse sheets of lymphoid cells; positive for CD20.
    • Often bilateral and associated with systemic B symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats).
  • (Choice C) Yolk Sac Tumor
    • Most common testicular tumor in infants and children, rare in adults.
    • Histology: Schiller-Duval bodies (resembles glomeruli).
    • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) is elevated (highly specific).
    • Grossly, it shows a yellow, mucinous appearance.
  • (Choice D) Teratoma
    • Composed of multiple tissue types (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm).
    • Grossly heterogeneous, with cysts and cartilage/bone-like structures.
    • Can be benign in children but malignant in adults.
    • No uniform cells like seminoma.

Key takeaway:

  • Most common testicular tumor in middle-aged adults (30-40 years).
  • Gross findings:
    • Well-circumscribed, homogeneous, gray-white mass, without necrosis or hemorrhage.
  • Histological findings:
    • Large uniform cells with clear cytoplasm (glycogen-rich).
    • Lymphocytic infiltration in the stroma.
    • Positive for immunohistochemical markers PLAP, OCT4, and c-KIT (CD117).

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy man who owns a pet shop presents with a 14-day history of asymptomatic left submental swelling. The swelling was approximately 1 x 2 cm, non-tender, rubbery, and non fluctuant with limited mobility. The patient was prescribed 250 mg of amoxicillin 3 times a day for 7 days without appreciable effect. Upon histopathological examination, the given finding is seen. Identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's submental lymphadenopathy, history of pet shop ownership (likely exposure to cats), and lack of response to amoxicillin suggest Cat Scratch Disease (CSD), caused by Bartonella henselae, a gram-negative bacillus.

Incorrect Choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Crohn's Disease
    • Crohn's primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract, not isolated lymph nodes.
    • Non-caseating granulomas are present in Crohn’s, but there is no necrotizing granulomatous inflammation with stellate abscesses, which are characteristic of CSD.
  • (Choice B) Berylliosis
    • Occurs in industrial workers exposed to beryllium (e.g., aerospace, nuclear, electronics industries).
    • Non-caseating granulomas in the lungs, mimicking sarcoidosis.
    • No history of beryllium exposure in this patient.
  • (Choice D) Syphilis
    • Treponema pallidum infection, presenting with painless genital ulcers (primary syphilis) or generalized lymphadenopathy (secondary syphilis).
    • Histology shows plasma cell infiltrates, not necrotizing granulomas.
    • No sexual history or other syphilitic symptoms in this case.

Key takeaway:

  • Caused by Bartonella henselae, transmitted via scratches, bites, or flea exposure from cats.
  • Chronic lymphadenopathy (submandibular, axillary, cervical, or inguinal nodes) lasting weeks to months.
  • Lymph nodes are non-tender, rubbery, and firm, with possible necrosis and granuloma formation.
  • Histopathology shows necrotizing granulomas with stellate microabscesses (a hallmark feature).
  • Serology (IgG/IgM for Bartonella) or PCR confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: Biopsy of a long bone was taken and the histology is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Paget's Disease of Bone (Osteitis Deformans) is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged, deformed, and structurally weak bones.

Histological Findings in Paget’s Disease:

  • Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone ("jigsaw puzzle" or "mosaic-like" appearance) due to irregular cement lines.
  • Increased osteoclastic activity followed by excessive, disorganized osteoblastic activity.
  • Hypervascular marrow with fibrotic changes.
  • Thickened trabeculae with disorganized architecture.

Incorrect Choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Osteoporosis
    • Bone mass is reduced, but histology shows thinning of trabeculae, not a mosaic pattern.
    • No abnormal remodeling, only increased bone resorption.
  • (Choice B) Osteosclerosis
    • Characterized by increased bone density, but without disorganized remodeling.
    • Seen in osteopetrosis and myelofibrosis, not Paget's.
  • (Choice C) Osteomalacia
    • Due to defective mineralization of bone matrix from vitamin D deficiency.
    • Histology shows excess unmineralized osteoid, not the mosaic pattern of Paget’s.

 Key takeaway:

  • Commonly affects long bones (femur, tibia), pelvis, skull, and spine.
  • Patients often have bone pain, deformities (bowing of long bones), and fractures.
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal calcium and phosphate levels.
  • Radiology: Enlarged bones with cortical thickening and lytic ("osteolytic-blastic") lesions.

questions.text: A teenager has a progressively increasing soft reddish swelling on his chest. It's histological appearance is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological image shows numerous vascular channels filled with blood, which is characteristic of a hemangioma. Clinically, the patient has a progressively enlarging reddish swelling on the chest, which is consistent with a vascular tumor.

Incorrect Choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Lipoma
    • Composed of mature adipose tissue, not vascular structures.
    • Appears as a soft, yellowish, subcutaneous mass, without a reddish tint.
  • (Choice C) Fibroadenoma
    • Found in the breast, not typically on the chest wall.
    • Composed of fibrous and glandular tissue, not blood vessels.
  • (Choice D) Fibroma
    • Composed of fibroblasts and collagen, not vascular elements.
    • Appears as a firm, whitish mass, not a reddish lesion.

Key takeaway:

  • Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors composed of proliferating blood vessels.
  • Common in children and adolescents, presenting as a soft, compressible, reddish lesion.
  • Histology:
    • Numerous capillary or cavernous vascular spaces.
    • Endothelial cell proliferation.
    • Red blood cells inside the lumens.

Types of Hemangiomas:

questions.text: Stunning of myocardium without any acute coronary syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also called stress-induced cardiomyopathy or "broken heart syndrome") is a condition characterized by transient left ventricular systolic dysfunction in the absence of acute coronary syndrome (no coronary artery occlusion).

Why is Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy the Correct Answer?

  • Stunning of the myocardium occurs due to acute catecholamine surge in response to emotional or physical stress.
  • Reversible dysfunction of the left ventricular apex ("apical ballooning") is seen on echocardiography.
  • No evidence of significant coronary artery disease (CAD) on angiography.
  • Typically affects postmenopausal women after extreme emotional distress.

Incorrect Choices explanation :

  • (Choice A) Subendocardial Infarction
    • Occurs due to partial ischemia of the myocardium caused by acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
    • Shows ST-segment depression on ECG and troponin elevation.
    • Not a stress-induced phenomenon without ACS.
  • (Choice B) Restrictive Cardiomyopathy
    • Characterized by diastolic dysfunction and stiff ventricular walls due to fibrosis or infiltration (e.g., amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis).
    • Not associated with myocardial stunning or catecholamine stress.
  • (Choice D) Transmural Infarction
    • Involves full-thickness myocardial necrosis due to complete coronary artery occlusion.
    • Associated with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
    • Permanent myocardial damage, unlike Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, which is reversible.

Key takeaway :  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy leads to myocardial stunning without acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
